main_topics: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection

questions.topic: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
questions.question: What is a key characteristic of a project?
options: It has an indefinite time frame.
It has a beginning and an end.

questions.topic: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a step in the project planning process?
options: Scheduling all tasks to be performed

questions.topic: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
questions.question: What is the main purpose of project management?
options: To increase the scope of a project
To plan, organize, and control project activities

questions.topic: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
questions.question: Who is typically responsible for managing a project's scope, schedule, and cost?

questions.topic: Introduction to Project Planning and Management
questions.question: Which of the following best describes a project plan?
options: A temporary document that is discarded after project initiation
A formal, approved document used to manage a project
A detailed guide for performing day-to-day project activities

questions.question: What is the most distinguishing feature of a project?
options: A project has a specific time frame.
A project follows a planned method.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key characteristic of a project?
options: A project is a one-time effort.

questions.question: What does it mean when a project is described as 'unique'?
options: It has a specific time frame.
Its result is different from other functions of the organization.

questions.question: Why is a project considered a temporary endeavor?
options: It has a clearly defined start and end time.

questions.question: Which of the following roles is responsible for the outcomes of a project?
What does a project typically involve?
options: A permanent team and ongoing activities
Varied activities with no specific objectives
A set of continuous processes with no end date

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of project planning?
options: To execute tasks as they arise
To define tasks, estimate resources, and provide a management framework

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a project?
options: Has a definite start and end time
Is a continuous process without a specific goal

questions.question: What does the project planning process typically include?
options: Ignoring risks and focusing solely on execution
Estimating project size and scope, scheduling tasks, and assessing risks
Planning only high-level goals without details

questions.question: In project planning, what are 'commitments'?
options: Tasks that are planned, documented, and agreed to by affected groups
Unplanned tasks that arise during the project
Resources that are unlimited and readily available
Objectives that are subject to change with no documentation

questions.question: What is a project plan?
options: A detailed financial report for the project
A formal, approved document used to manage and control a project
A list of project team members
An informal note about project goals

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a step in the project planning process?
options: Define the organization used to execute the project
Identify the known risks in executing the project
Define personal goals of the project manager
Estimate the resources required to perform each task

questions.question: What is the purpose of project planning?
options: To define each major task, estimate time and resources, and provide a framework for management review and control
To set up a new company
To ensure the project has unlimited resources

questions.question: How is a project defined according to the provided context?
options: A permanent effort to accomplish a goal
An endeavor with no specific timeframe
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product or service
A continuous process with no end date

questions.question: Which document evolves as the project moves through its various stages?
Which of the following best defines Project Management?
options: A process of achieving project objectives through a set of activities within a specific time frame.
A temporary endeavor undertaken to create a unique product or service.
A method of maintaining ongoing operations within an organization.
A strategy for indefinite programs extending across multiple business objectives.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Project Management?
options: To establish a permanent team structure.
To integrate and coordinate project tasks and resources for goal achievement.
To provide continuous monitoring of all organizational activities.
To develop strategies for indefinite project extensions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of a project?
options: It has a definite start and end date.
It focuses on maintaining existing systems.

questions.question: Why are projects considered 'temporary endeavors'?
options: Their objectives are broad and undefined.
They have a clear start and end date.
They do not require planning and management.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a purpose of Project Management?
options: To meet or exceed stakeholders' needs and expectations.
To effectively schedule and control project activities.

questions.topic: Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
questions.question: What is one of the primary responsibilities of a project manager?
options: Managing the project's scope, schedule, and cost

questions.topic: Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
questions.question: Which skill is NOT essential for a project manager according to the document?

questions.topic: Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
questions.question: Who is responsible for negotiating a resolution to team member resource conflicts?

questions.topic: Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
questions.question: A project manager must provide input to the performance reviews of:

questions.topic: Role and Responsibilities of a Project Manager
questions.question: Which of the following is a key duty of a project manager?
options: Serving as the central point of contact for the project

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a key characteristic of a project?
options: A project has a beginning and an end.
A project follows a planned, organized method to meet its objectives.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of project planning?
options: To manage and control a project using an approved document.
To define each major task, estimate time and resources required, and provide a framework for management review and control.
To dissolve the project team once objectives are met.
To ensure that the project has a manager responsible for its outcomes.

questions.question: Which phase of the project cycle involves carrying out further research into the people affected by a problem?
What is a key aspect of lesson learning in the project cycle?
options: It makes the project cycle appear linear, with one tool following another.
It ensures that planning tools are only used at the start of the project.
It emphasizes that many planning tools can be used at any stage of the project.
It requires that once a project is designed, it cannot be changed.

questions.question: Which of the following is a purpose of project management?
options: To keep the project team unchanged throughout the project.
To integrate project purposes, people, and processes.
To ensure that the project has no constraints.
To make sure all stakeholders agree on every decision.

questions.question: What is a need according to the context of Need Assessment?
options: A discrepancy between the current and desired state
A performance that meets the current standard

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of a good needs analysis?
options: Focuses on the results that should be obtained
Provides a subjective basis for decision-making
Involves all stakeholders in establishing priorities
Is a cyclic process that integrates within strategic planning

questions.question: What is a primary aim of conducting a needs assessment?
options: To implement a project without beneficiary input
To assess the extent and causes of community social problems
To evaluate the project's long-term impact
To design a project without constraints

questions.question: What is the purpose of collecting information on demography during a needs assessment?
options: To understand the target population's service needs

questions.question: What does SWOT analysis assess in a needs assessment context?
options: External threats without considering internal strengths
Both internal strengths and weaknesses, and external opportunities and threats

questions.topic: Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a needs assessment?
options: To allocate resources for project implementation
To identify performance problems and establish priorities
To create a project budget and timeline

questions.topic: Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection
questions.question: Which type of information is typically collected during a needs assessment?

questions.topic: Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection
questions.question: What is an example of a formal needs assessment method?

questions.topic: Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection
questions.question: Which analysis method is commonly used for needs assessment in community development projects?

questions.topic: Types of Needs Assessment and Information Collection
questions.question: Why is it important to conduct a capacity assessment after needs assessment?
options: To ensure all project activities are on schedule
To identify strengths the community can use to address problems
To finalize project budgets and resource allocation
To evaluate the project's impact and outcomes

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of conducting a stakeholder analysis at the beginning of the project design?
options: To understand which organizations or groups of people have an interest in the issues
To select the project team members

questions.question: Who are considered primary stakeholders in a project?
options: Those who only fund the project
Those who benefit from, or are adversely affected by, an activity
Those who work in the project team

questions.question: Why is it important to identify sub-groups within a community during stakeholder analysis?
options: To divide the project tasks equally
To account for different interests and impacts on these sub-groups
To ensure all sub-groups receive equal funding

questions.question: What should be done if stakeholders are not identified at the project planning stage?
options: The project is at risk of failure
The project plan should be rewritten

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a main area covered in stakeholder analysis?
What is the main purpose of conducting a problem analysis?
options: To understand the causes and effects of problems

questions.question: What does a 'problem tree' primarily help to identify?
options: Causes and effects of a problem

questions.question: What are the two levels of causes identified in a problem analysis?
In a problem tree, what does the 'trunk' represent?
Which of the following is a consequence of a high pregnancy rate among teenage girls, according to the problem analysis?
What does the 'S' in SMART objectives stand for?
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of SMART objectives?
Why is it important for objectives to be 'Measurable' in the SMART framework?
options: To ensure objectives are easy to achieve
To allow for tracking and assessing progress

questions.question: In the SMART framework, why should objectives be 'Relevant'?
options: To align with the broader goals and needs of the organization
To make objectives easy to achieve

questions.question: What does the 'T' in SMART objectives represent?
What is the primary purpose of a Logical Framework Approach?
options: To make the project management rigid and inflexible.
To identify the management team for a project.
To strengthen project design, implementation, and evaluation.
To ensure that the project has a large budget.

questions.question: What are the four levels of objectives in a Logical Framework?
Which statement best describes the role of 'Assumptions' in a Logical Framework?
options: Assumptions are predictions about the project's budget.
Assumptions are conditions that could affect the project's success.
Assumptions are detailed descriptions of each project activity.
Assumptions are the project's primary objectives.

questions.question: Why is it important to involve primary stakeholders in the development of a Logical Framework?
options: Because they provide the project's financial resources.
Because they are responsible for writing the final report.
Because they offer valuable insights and ensure the project meets their needs.
Because they can predict the exact outcomes of the project.

questions.question: What question does the 'Indicators' column in a Logical Framework address?
options: What are the potential problems along the way?
How will the project be funded?
How do we know when we have achieved our objectives?

questions.question: What is the purpose of a project budget in action planning?
options: To estimate the time required for project completion
To prepare a valid estimate of the costs associated with project activities
To determine the number of personnel needed
To identify potential risks in the project

questions.question: What should an activity planning worksheet help us consider?
options: What types of inputs will be needed

questions.question: Why should the action plan be viewed as a flexible document?
options: Because it is completed during the execution phase
Because it needs to be updated based on project progress
Because it includes only financial information
Because it does not require stakeholder involvement

questions.question: What is the starting point for developing an action plan?
Which of the following is a key component of a project budget?
options: Cost estimates for inputs and resources

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a project budget?
options: To reduce the project's overall expenses
To prepare a valid estimate of the costs associated with project activities
To ensure that all team members are paid equally

questions.question: What should be considered when developing a project budget?
options: Only the direct costs of materials
Only the salaries of the project team

questions.question: During which stage should the project budget be developed?
options: In the final stage of project implementation
At the early stages of project design
Only if the project faces financial difficulties

questions.question: What is the role of a finance specialist in project budgeting?
options: To ensure team members are satisfied with their salaries
To help project design team make realistic estimates for project expenses
To approve all expenditures without oversight
To manage only the revenue side of the budget

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a project budget?
options: Estimates for all inputs and resources
Identification of all sources of revenue

questions.question: What is the primary objective of project monitoring?
options: To assess the needs of the community
To track the progress against planned activities
To evaluate the success after project completion

questions.question: Which component is not typically monitored in project management?
What is a key reason for conducting a baseline survey before project implementation?
options: To establish baseline data for comparison

questions.question: What role does evaluation play in project management?
options: It assesses whether project objectives have been met
It focuses solely on financial auditing
It replaces the need for monitoring
It is only concerned with stakeholder satisfaction

questions.question: What is a common timing for conducting an evaluation in a project lifecycle?
options: Midterm and end of the project

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of monitoring in a project?
options: To assess the project's impact after completion
To track the project's progress and activities regularly
To develop a budget for the project

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component typically monitored in a project?
What is the difference between monitoring and evaluation in project management?
options: Monitoring is done at the end of the project, while evaluation is ongoing.
Monitoring focuses on inputs and outputs, while evaluation focuses on outcomes and impact.
Monitoring is for external stakeholders, while evaluation is for internal stakeholders.
There is no significant difference between monitoring and evaluation.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key element included in a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) plan?
Why is it important to involve stakeholders in the monitoring and reviewing process?
options: To ensure stakeholders financially contribute to the project
To identify and address stakeholder needs and expectations
To ensure the project manager has assistance in data collection

questions.question: What is the primary objective of monitoring in a project?
options: To ensure budget is not exceeded
To identify and solve problems during implementation
To assess the impact of the project

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a good indicator in an M&E plan?
options: It should be vague to cover multiple areas
It should depend on personal judgments

questions.question: What is the role of 'Assumptions' in a log frame?
options: They define the project's main objectives
They identify external factors that may affect project success
They list the stakeholders involved in the project

questions.question: What is the purpose of conducting a baseline survey before project implementation?
options: To gather initial data for comparison with future progress
To evaluate the project's final impact

questions.question: What is the main aim of evaluation in the context of project implementation?
options: To measure project efficiency and impact

questions.question: What is the main purpose of project monitoring?
options: To check the quality of outputs
To track project activities against the plan

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of internal monitoring?
What type of monitoring focuses on tracking the project's budget and non-financial resources?
Which level of monitoring focuses on ensuring that the expected results of interventions are achieved?
What is the focus of external monitoring?
options: Tracking internal resources like staff and budget
Evaluating the management style of the project manager
Monitoring the financial health of the organization

questions.question: What is the primary objective of evaluation in project management?
options: To monitor the daily activities of the project
To ascertain whether the project has achieved its intended objectives
To allocate resources for the project

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a specific criterion used in evaluation?
When is evaluation typically conducted during a project?
options: Only at the start of the project
Periodically, mid-term, at the end, and years after completion

questions.question: Who can conduct external evaluations of a project?
Which of the following statements about evaluation is true?
options: It is only conducted at the end of a project.
It provides recommendations for future project improvements.
It focuses solely on financial aspects.
It doesn't require any baseline data.

questions.question: What is the primary objective of evaluation in project management?
options: To ascertain whether the project has achieved its intended objectives
To provide ongoing performance feedback to the project manager

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a criterion used for evaluation by big organizations?
What does 'Efficiency' measure in the context of project evaluation?
options: The extent of achievement of development objectives
Whether the resources used for activities are appropriate in terms of output
The impact of project implementation on the problem addressed
The long-term sustainability of the project's outcomes

questions.question: When is an 'ex post evaluation' typically conducted?
options: During the implementation of the project
At the end of the project
Years after the completion of the project

questions.question: Who can conduct external evaluations of a project?
What is the primary objective of evaluation in project management?
options: To ascertain whether the project has achieved its intended objectives

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of monitoring commonly used in development work?
What does the 'If-and-Then' test in a log frame help to determine?
What should be included in a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) plan?
options: A description of intended results, indicators, targets, data source, baseline values, and responsible persons

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a good indicator?
options: It requires complex data collection tools
